text: Patient: Um my sister and my great-niece. Doctor: Sister and great-niece. A-and i-i-is your great-niece working or is she at home? Is she- Patient: She-she work. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhm. She probably gon’ be there Doctor: Okay. Well um, you might be right that the PSA level could be rising. We’ll find out by uh later this afternoon or tomorrow morning at the latest. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, I I did want to speak to you about um a research study that we’re doing that I think would be a good fit for you and I wanted to give you some details about that. Patient: Mm-kay. Doctor: And then give you some time to uh look at some written information that I’ll give you to take home. And you can look at that with your sister and your great-niece and the three of you can decide together whether you think this might be good idea for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And um I just wanted to um write some notes down. And then after I write these notes, I’m going to give you some detailed information about the the clinical trials. So, if if you are not at J_____ H_____. If you were just seeing a medical oncologist without- private practice or community um then the next step for someone like you, where the cancer might be growing or progressing despite the Abiraterone-

text: Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time. Doctor: Yeah and by then we’ll know what trial makes sense um to offer… Patient: You know I do see on the internet, I think it was a… Doctor: Yeah Patient: British article about immunotherapy with prostate cancer… Doctor: Mhmm, Yes. Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. It’s um you know the ones that we have just for prostate doesn’t allow people who’ve had chemo, but we have a couple more in the phase one group that potentially will. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It just opened, it just opened. Patient: And what is a PSMA?

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. We do have trials where we're trying to even build on that. Okay, so hormones plus chemo plus immune therapy or hormones plus hormone therapy plus immune system drugs. Patient: Right. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? Wow. Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, that is why. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Aximun scan may help and may also confuse thing. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But I'll hear from you anything that says we got to rush to therapy make a decision right now that I just need to figure out. We are adding Aximun scans to our scanning facility but we don't do them now. Patient: Right.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know that’s an early phase—Phase I study. That clearly has no data as to whether it works. And so you could window it in at this point, but if the scans when we get them show that the stuff that’s in your liver is even big in other areas, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know whether or not you have the willingness or sort of the time to sort of participate in something that’s you know experimental of that nature of a brand new drug is questionable. But some people clearly want to avoid chemotherapy at all costs and are willing to try that even if you know it doesn’t work and they were to miss that opportunity for chemotherapy. So everybody sort of chooses based on who they talk to, who their neighbors are, who’s been through chemo. Doctor: What they are willing to think about. Patient: Yes, I have the time. Yeah. Doctor: Time is one thing, but again you know what the cancer is going to do is the other. Patient: Side effects and all that, yeah, I don’t know what, yeah. Doctor: So those would be potentially three options. If we’re going to go chemotherapy, whether we add in the Vitamin C or not; you get the infusion, you don’t know whether it’s the real thing or Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you get the real chemo. The other one is the immune therapy which my reservation at this point is the gasping thing. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

text: Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling. Doctor: Yeah. No, I don’t want to wait until you get paralyzed either. Patient: It would be in my arms. Doctor: Right. Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. text: Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: You had to scare me like that. I have no idea. Family Member: I just gave him some M and M’s. Good thing I brought them in. Not M and M’s but Good and Plenty. text: Patient: The Erlida? Doctor: The Erlida, yeah. Patient: Two weeks ago I think. Doctor: Two weeks. Okay. Patient: Well, let's see now. Family Member 1: When you came last week? No? Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them.

text: Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found) Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost?

text: Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: I need to make an appointment with him and do the uh. Doctor: For the scope and all that. Patient: Scope. Doctor: So he makes sure the passage is okay and the bladder is safe and all that. Alright so I’ll let them know if you’re okay with it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay and uh then we’ll plan for your appointment after the cryo and everything is done. So forget about the June appointment. We’ll just schedule something later on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because probably the whole month of June will be taken up so most likely it will be somewhere end of July or so. Okay? Patient: So how do I make the appointment for the scope? Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
